head.title: OpSail 2000: It's Not Nice to Snub the Spectators

hedline.hl1: OpSail 2000: It's Not Nice to Snub the Spectators

abstract.p: Matthew Pimm letter says he suspects that lure of television cameras and not unfavorable tides prompted OpSail organizers to shorten parade of tall ships up the Hudson (July 5 article)

block.p: Re ''A Fine Fourth, With One Flaw'' (editorial, July 6):
Re ''A Fine Fourth, With One Flaw'' (editorial, July 6):
I would like to emphasize to those who organized OpSail 2000 that for us, the shortened parade of sail was more than what you say was ''one glitch in an otherwise glorious day.''

You note that OpSail officials cited the prospect of unfavorable tidal conditions as an excuse for the shortened sail, and you say that ''tides are not all that difficult to predict.'' Indeed, to those of us who spend our weekends sailing in New York Harbor, the reason that OpSail cited doesn't ring true.

I wonder if the sight of the tall ships crossing each other below 47th Street for the television cameras was the real reason for the shortened route. Perhaps in the future OpSail ads should have fine print, like those for cars: ''OpSail, the Greatest Event in Maritime History (for qualified spectators only).''
